intro: Disadena, commonly known as the ghostflower, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Ericaceae. It consists of a single species, Disadena uniflora, native to the southeastern United States. The plant is characterized by its showy, violet-colored flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It has a low-growing, mat-forming habit with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Disadena is adapted to acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as woodlands and thickets.
